title: How to Grow a Pumpkin

content: hey there i'm nicola chatham and today i'm answering a sprouter's question about pumpkins but before i get there i just want to tell you a quick little story from my childhood because it is related just it's strangely related um for the first couple of years of my life my both my parents were vets and so it was not uncommon to see my dad with his um halfway up a cow performing the very important task of artificial insemination now today's question has something to do with that you might be thinking what the hell is she doing today well uh this lady is having a very common problem and it's something that i used to have trouble with as well and it's about her pumpkins basically they are not being fertilized that she's getting the little round um ovums the little the little babies starting on the vine but then they are falling off without growing they're rotting and not developing into beautiful pumpkins so i'm going to teach you a little trick that my friend rosina buchmann taught me and it's basically we're going to be artificially inseminating the pumpkin flowers what with the decrease in bees in the world we need to give them a bit of a hand and get in there and actually pull the male flowers off and then we'll take the uh the petals off from around the edge and plunk him in the middle of the female flowers and i'll just give you a little demonstration of how that's done okay so this is a male flower and you can tell that because it hasn't got a little uh bulb or bulbous part of the young pumpkin at the bottom and also you can see inside there's just one little stamen in there so we can pick this one and use him to fertilize our female flowers whereas this one you can see is a female flower it's got the little young pumpkin the ovum there and inside you can also see if i put it into the sun you can see it's got lots and lots of little stamen in there instead of just the one so that's a female flower you're looking for the bulb at the bottom and then lots of the little stamen things in the middle so i've taken the male flower that we picked before and just pulled off his little pedals so that it's easier to expose the pollen and then it's just a matter of poking him in the middle and job done this will develop into a uh a beautiful big pumpkin and they'll start to look like this instead of looking like this and eventually they will look like these ones i don't know if you can see them very well it's a bit dark but i've got three clustered right outside my back door here before i learnt this trick i lost i only had one pumpkin in the season um once discovering it this year i've now got i think i've got eight pumpkins growing on the same vine so it's really effective and it's a great little thing to know um i'm playing around with a new iphone app today and i'm pretending to come from the past to tell you this little gem of wisdom from the past because it's things that we are losing touch with in modern culture so i hope that you enjoy an abundance of pumpkins this season and you have a great week and thanks for the questions you can send them in and if i can help you i'll put them on sprout all right cheers have a great day i'm nicola chatham and like it if you like it ciao

original_title: How Do You Grow A Pumpkin?
content: it is a fall tradition for so many families a visit to the pumpkin patch but what goes on long before we show up with our wagons how do you grow a great pumpkin good question there's other Brown just east of Wyoming we've been here since 10 o'clock this morning is a corn playground next to blank orange canvases we're bringing a bag home to paint today on a 40 acre labor of love I used to bring my kids here when they were that little starting over you're starting from scratch every single year every single year that's true Val Whitner owns Lentz pumpkin patch my customer's always amazed that we didn't put them there can you imagine there's 40 acres here we did not put them there they grew there and they have to pull the vine off of the stem all of these pumpkins started as single seeds that Val planted herself back in the beginning June I get this question every year and very many times people think that pumpkins grow in the weeds and that when this pumpkin rots that next spring it will just come back another pumpkin wouldn't that be nice that would be one that'd be nice once the seeds sprout the plant gets bigger and bushier and starts to send out vines by early July there's a flower the flower opens one day for about four hours it needs to be pollinated which is why Lance has bees on site right behind the flower once it's pollinated it starts growing a pumpkin and just gets bigger and bigger the flower dies and falls off and the pumpkin just keeps growing many varieties start out green before turning the color of Halloween that's when the leaves start falling exposing the pumpkins for everyone to pick their own hey bear can you tell me which is your favorite pumpkin so what happens to all the pumpkins that don't get sold I love that question we leave them here and they get disked in in the fall and it is good for the ground to have that rotten matter she does a lot of work she does a ton of work to make this a very nice place do you like pumpkins what's your favorite part about doing all this at the brown I love talking to people WCCO all the way till November first and then not so much for news no no a lot of cute kids in that story yeah now as you can imagine lenses open 7 days a week this time of year all the way up until October 31st and like many pumpkin patches truly as a family endeavor to keep things going yeah Val's three daughters worked there and her brother-in-law does a spraying fertilizing cultivating and plowing there a good question for Heather please e-mail it by going to wcco.com/links that val was thrilled to see this

title: How to Grow a Pumpkin
original_title: How To Plant Pumpkins
content: hi I'm Lindsay Evans I'm a garden designer when I'm not designing Gardens you'll find me out on my allotment tending to my flowers and vegetables the best way of growing pumpkins and butternut squash is is to create planting pockets for them dig a hole 30 centimetres square 30 centimetres deep and fill it with some compost put a mound of soil onto the top and then you can plant the seeds or the young plants directly into these mounds where they can feed off the compost finning you should plant two seeds per planting pockets on their sides around about May and June I always start my seeds off inside I fill a three inch pot with some compost and then drop two seeds into each pot I always top the pots with a little bit of vermiculite this is actually perlite it's a lightweight substance and it stops the tops of the pots drying out I then place the pots in a propagator give them a bit of water and wait for them to germinate once they've germinated I move them into the greenhouse and gradually harden them off that means getting them used to the outside air temperature bringing them out in the day and taking them back at night before I plant them up into their planting pockets don't assume that the female flowers those are the ones with the little baby butternut squashes forming behind them have been pollinated you may need to hand pollinate this is quite simple just take a cotton bud or a small paintbrush and dip it into the center of one of the male flowers then transfer some of the pollen into the female flowers that way you can ensure that all of the flowers have been pollinated you will be very lucky if you get as many as six butternut squashes per plant they don't produce many but there really are worth waiting for they also take up an awful lot of space and I've had quite a bit of success planting my butternut squash it in between my sweet corn canes because then you get to use the space underneath the sweet corn and they quite enjoy growing with one another pumpkins and squashes can be damaged by soil borne fungal diseases so to prevent this lift them off the ground using bricks or something similar this also helps to protect the fruit while it's ripening the squashes are ripe when the skin is hard and there's about two inches of stem cut them away from the main plant using a sharp knife make sure you harvest your squashes before the Frost's so those are my tips for getting the most out of your butternut squash and pumpkin crops

content: hello everybody today i'll be showing you how to grow successful pumpkin patch and how to have a good pumpkin yield i've been growing pumpkins for quite a while like seven or eight years and successful pumpkin patch like this in this video so come on guys i'll show you how to grow pumpkins so first off pumpkins are a rich um feeder and compost they love rich compost soils are full of nutrients many years before i did this year these pumpkins planted them along this row i never really amended the soil extra so i was wondering over the winter if that would help so i amended it with about three bags of compost and it is absolutely incredible absolutely it works compost is one of the key main factors that help pumpkins grow another thing that pumpkins need in order to grow is tons and tons and tons of sunshine so here as you see we planted them at the edge of the garden so they could vine out and catch all the sunshine sunshine they can and another thing is while when you're planting your pumpkins where to plant them in your garden never plant them deep in a garden because they find out so crazy i mean this vine right here is approaching 30 feet so don't plant it until they're in the middle of your garden because simply you will take over your garden and you'll have nothing else it will take up all the space and it'll just be pumpkins so plant at the edge of your garden and that's what i did this year and it's a success now here this year we have really really really hot summer and when i mean really hot i mean pretty much 90s every day every single day so and not a lot of rain so the soil dries up so quickly it becomes so parched it's so cracked that you gotta water it often almost i gotta water every other day and the thing is if you don't water them often enough see these weaves see this leaf how was how it has those veins this is a water pressure and as you if you ever didn't if you already grow pumpkins and you just wanted a girl know how to grow better pumpkins if you ever realized how during on some really hot days your leaves just wilt yes because that doesn't mean your plant is dying it just means that it's lacking water and it just needs watering because then the leaves go back up because it has more water to fulfill to refill the leaves so that's one key thing to water your pumpkins a lot of water i tend to give them twice the amount i think they need because they need that much now there are several problems that pumpkin growers will encounter and number one is this as you see these leaves have a powdery fungus on them and that's called powdery mildew just i don't know if you can see that but i have i'm sorry i have it on my hand and you could it's basically a fungus that forms on your pumpkin plants at the towards the end of the season as you see but it spreads spread like fire jesus this wasn't even here about a week ago so and now it's everywhere well not everywhere but almost on every leaf all signs of it so powdery mildew it won't damage your whole pumpkin patch won't kill it off but it will slow it down and uh the best way to avoid it and avoid the major effects of it is pretty much to plant them pumpkins in may and june because this comes towards the end of the season so plant them early and you will be fine another thing is that there's a moth that flies around it's called a vine door and vinegar and it lays eggs in your pumpkin plant all across your pumpkin plant and it rolls into this plant the larvae and makes it pretty much squishy and die but the good thing about the pumpkin is on the cement like that one so we could put the roots down into the ground and for the vine borer eggs the only way i found to deal with them is to pretty much pick off the eggs the only way i found that works now when it comes to planting the proper pumpkin variety there's not much to it if you want to make jack-o-lanterns out of your pumpkins plant jack-o'-lantern pumpkin or connecticut field if you want a a baking pumpkin the plant sugar pie pumpkin and you can make a pie out of the jack-o-lantern pumpkin but it'll be really liquidy and it won't be good now i've seen a lot of people on title: How to Grow a Pumpkin
original_title: How to Grow Pumpkins in a Container
content: because of the sprawling nature of pumpkin vines some city gardeners feel they can't grow the seasonal plant however the small varieties of pumpkins grow well in large containers and are just has popular at Halloween as their bigger relatives things you will need pumpkin seeds container potting soil or garden soil compost trellis looking at garden in catalog or online for pumpkin seeds that produce small or miniature pumpkins purchase seats for one or more varieties sugar pie small sugar and Jack bean little are three proven varieties these small pumpkins can grow in containers because the pumpkin vines are strong enough to support them larger varieties produce fruit that divine cannot support and are unsuitable for containers purchase or find a container for the pumpkin garden a plastic kiddie pool is an inexpensive container that is easy to find although any large well-drained container will work prepare the kiddie pool for the garden by punching holes in the bottom of the pool for drainage purchase or make a trellis or to the trellis encourages the vines to grow up instead of sprawling out across the ground position a container in a sunny place in the yard prepare the soil for the pumpkin container garden fill the container with potting soil or garden soil amended with compost the compost gives the pumpkin plants an extra nutrient boost during the growing season plant the pumpkin seeds 1 inch deep in mounds 3 seats per mound the number of mounts depends on the size of the container mount should be positioned four feet apart so you may have room for only one mound in a small container place the trellis behind the container or in the case of a kiddie pool container place it inside the pool and push it through the pool bottom if the pool is large enough add two or three trellises and tie strings between them to give the pumpkins another supportive place to grow water and fertilize the pumpkin plants regularly as the plants grow train them on the trellis and strings keep the bed weed free by hand pulling any weeds as you see them avoid using insecticides bees pollinate the flowers to produce the pumpkins if you must spray do it in the evening after the blossoms have closed for the day harvest when the pumpkin rind is hard to the touch and the color is a deep orange and all the white varieties cut the pumpkin from the vine using pruning shears leaving a a two inch stem attached to the pumpkin tips warnings be sure to purchase seeds of a small variety pumpkin the larger fruits are not suitable for container growing

title: How to Grow a Pumpkin
original_title: How to Carve a Pumpkin
content: how to carve a pumpkin the first jack-o'-lanterns were carved centuries ago to ward off evil spirits now we use them to lure little ghosts and goblins to our home but the technique remains the same you need a pumpkin a sharp knife a crayon or marker a large spoon or ice-cream scooper and a small candle glow stick or battery-operated light optional salt a baking sheet a carving template a thumbtack and petroleum jelly step 1 choose a pumpkin that's large and smooth with a stem of at least two inches if you plan to put a candle inside choose a gourd that's at least nine inches tall pumpkins with smaller stems rot quickly step 2 draw a circle or hexagon on the top of the pumpkin an inch or two below the stem don't worry if it's not perfect but make sure it's a little bigger than your fist step 3 carve through the pattern with a sharp knife which requires less force and is therefore safer angle your cut so the top of your circle is wider than the bottom which will ensure that the top fits snugly in place step 4 remove the top and clean out the pumpkin seeds and stringy membranes with the scooper continue scraping the inside until the walls are about half an inch thick otherwise it will be hard to carve for a delicious and healthy treat wash and sprinkle the seeds with salt and then toast them in the oven on a baking sheet step 5 draw the eyes nose and mouth or any other pattern you want like perhaps van Gogh's famous paintings the starry night if you're not good at drawing find a carving template online or at a store fasten it to the pumpkin and use a thumbtack to poke holes along the lines step 6 use your knife to cut through the pattern you've just drawn remember that cuts that connect to each other will remove the entire piece in between so cut around anything you want to stay intact like teeth or a wart on the nose step 7 make disconnected cuts and scrapes to allow the light from inside the pumpkin to shine through without removing whole pieces a good technique for drawing outlines or scenes or for creating more definition in a face like glowing pupils to keep the edges from browning before the big night dab on a little petroleum jelly to lock in moisture step 8 place a small candle and light it when you're ready to show off your work if there's a large opening level with the candle like a mouth light the flame through it so you don't burn your hand if your flame is weak or keeps going out it's not getting enough oxygen you cut a small opening in the top of the pumpkin hidden from sight behind the stem step 9 if you're not keen on having a real flame use a glow stick or battery-powered light did you know because pumpkins weren't common in Europe early jack-o'-lanterns were made out of turnips [Music]

the little pumpkins after strong the faces on using a black sharpie and where did I get my inspiration from my little punches so that one's that one and I'm going to do another one it's gonna have that base on it and there are my three little pumpkins which I drew from the little punches that I had I thought giant pumpkin which is pretty dirty so I figured I will wash off the back of this try and get all this dirt so now that my pumpkin is fairly clean I'm just gonna Pat it dry with some paper towels so now the first thing that I want to do is cut off this top and I want to make a cut big enough to put my hand in so I can dig out all of the from inside and I like to do this in the sink simply because it saves me a mess so I'm just going to cut through and you need a really big sharp knife to do this and I want to cut all the way around like this now inside you have the pulp and the seeds and I like to separate the seeds out while I'm pulling out the pulp now here I have a bowl for my seeds and the pulp I'm just going to place into the sink so I just want to take my hand in and dig out the inside like this and then I just separate out the seeds as best that I can because I'm going to wash them before I roast them and just place the pulp in the sink to be discarded or you could use it for a pie or something else and you want to keep doing this until your pumpkin is clean on the inside now once you've gotten out all that you can with your hands and I just like to take a spoon and kind of scrape the sides and get off any kind of extra pumpkin that was left in there like this and once it's fairly clean inside we can start carving now to carve a pumpkin I want to pick out which side is the best or what kind of face do I want well this sides been in the dirt so I don't really want that and so I just kind of turn it and I think I'm gonna go with this side here that's my surface then I'm gonna use a pencil and just draw an outline of the face that I want to make now it's a bit hard to see with the pencil as you can see I've drawn in the eyes and the mouth so I'm going to now trace it with a black magic marker now when you're drawing this with the black magic marker you want to make sure that you're not going to draw over a part that's not going to get cut out so right here I have a tooth I don't know if you can see that on the camera so instead of drawing a straight line across for my mouth I'm just gonna come down and draw my tooth in like that because I don't want to otherwise they'll have the black line there and now that I have my face I'm going to cut it out and I'm gonna start cutting out the eye and you want to cut outside of the black line like this and you want to make sure to cut all the way through the pumpkin and keep cutting until all of this is cut around now curves are the hardest to do and it just takes a little patience there now once you have the whole outline cut out you can just cut the center out of the piece like that I break it up so that it's easier to pull out stick for some reason sometimes and once you get that first piece out and the rest of it's easier to get out because then you can just kind of pull it and you may have to break it up into pieces so now once you have those pieces out you just want to clean it up but I kind of trimming off all the excess pumpkin like this in there you have your first high of the pumpkin and you want to just continue this for the rest of the pumpkin face and once the face is pretty cleaned out I'm just going to stand it on its side and then kind of just get rid of any kind of things that are hanging down on the inside of the pumpkin like these little things here so that it doesn't affect your lighting when you go to put the light in it and kind of smooth it out it's your finger okay so that looks pretty good and now I'm ready to put the top on it so I have this little tea light candle and you can find these in most dollar stores or grocery stores and I'm just going to place that down into the center and then I'm gonna place the top on now I'm not going to like this until tonight and I'll take a picture of it then but there you have my little pumpkin

title: How to Grow a Pumpkin
original_title: How Do PUMPKINS GROW FROM SEEDS For HALLOWEEN | Pumpkins for KIDS
content: in this video I'm gonna show you how to grow pumpkins from seeds for Halloween if you want to grow your own pumpkins then you should be thinking about it in the spring pumpkin is a very tender vegetable the seeds do not germinate in cold soil and the seedlings are injured by frost so do not plant until all danger of frost is passed and the soil is thoroughly warmed up May is the ideal time if you don't you'll be faced with disappointment of picking your pumpkin from the supermarket shelves instead it's a shame that these magnificent autumn vegetables are so easily forgotten because growing a pumpkin is great fun for all the family especially for Halloween there's a pumpkin to suit every home at Halloween from the tiny pumpkin to the enormous pumpkin but before you begin growing giant pumpkins it's wise to think about how much space you have to spare if you prefer traditional size pumpkins then it's a perfect choice for carving and making pumpkin pies for something slightly different why not try a small attractive variety pumpkin the green and orange pattern fruits they are the perfect size for popping in the microwave so when do so pumpkins pumpkins require warm daytime temperatures of between eighteen and thirty degrees Celsius at 68 degrees Fahrenheit and prefer a minimum nighttime temperature of 16 degrees Celsius at 61 degrees Fahrenheit at least until they're planted 8 in cooler areas pumpkins can be sown outdoors from April to mid-may for transplanting outside later on when temperatures have risen however if so in space is at a premium then you may prefer to wait until the soil is warmed up in late May in early June and then so directly in Scituate doors whether you choose to start them in pots or in the garden it's best to sow two seeds per hole and then thin out the weakest plants later on if you are direct so in pumpkins outdoors start them off under cloak shoes to give them the best start so how'd you grow a pumpkin so the step is to sell pumpkin seeds on their side in a small seven and a half centimeter that's three inch pot of seed compost in a depth of about 2.5 centimeters that's a been inch step to place them in a propagator or seal the pots inside a plastic bag at a temperature of about 20 Celsius that's 68 degrees Fahrenheit until germination which takes about five to seven days step 3 once germinated grow the pumpkin plant on for about 4 weeks until they are large enough to be transplanted outdoors step 4 gradually acclimatized them to outdoor conditions over seven to ten days before transplanting pumpkins into warm well-drained humors rich soil in full Sun with shelter from winds choose a spot that receives at least six hours of direct Sun per day and prepare the soil in advance adding plenty of well rotted manure or compost step 5 planting distances can range from 90 centimeters apart to 3 metres apart depending on the variety so you will need to check the seed packet at each planting station pile the soil into mains about 15 centimetres high that's about 6 inches plant each pumpkin plant on top of the mound to ensure good drainage and keep them well watered until they established step 6 pumpkins enjoy plenty of nitrogen so they will appreciate a feed of general fertilizer a few weeks after planting they will begin to produce long stems which can be trained in a circle around the plant to prevent them spreading too far they have deep roots in a normally quite capable of finding their own water within the soil but in very dry periods some supplementary watering may be required so how'd you pollinate pumpkins pumpkins are normally insect pollinated but if the fruits are not setting then you may need to hand pollinate them female pumpkin flowers can be identified by a swollen bump at the base of the bloom which male flowers don't have so you can easily tell don't be alarmed if the first few flowers are all male this is normal and you will start to find female flowers developing soon after is the flowers develop pick a single male flower and remove its petals press it against the center of each female flower if you prefer you can tickle the center of each flower with a small paintbrush to transfer the pollen from the male flower if you're growing pumpkins for Halloween then you will be hoping for the largest fruits possible select just two or three pumpkins per plant and remove all others to focus the plants energy on your chosen fruit so how do you harvest pumpkins leave your pumpkins on the plant for as long as possible till the skin is hardened and the fruit start to crack near the stem be sure to harvest them before the first frost though cut each fruit from the stem leaving several inches of the stem attached so here is my best pumpkin growing tips pumpkins can be prone to rotten if they're sitting on wet grained if necessary you can raise the fruits off the ground using a wooden board or a large upturned seed tray when growing pumpkins you can help the fruits to ripen but remove in any foliage that is shading them in cool seasons you may need to harvest pumpkins in a few weeks before Halloween and bring them into a warm room to help them ripen in time so how do we use pumpkins well they can be used as table decorations place them on some colorful autumn leaves that you've collected or if you're really creative make some play settings with them for your party dinner guests you can also make Halloween carvings small pumpkins can look very effective and are easier for young children to handle there are lots of free templates on the internet from simple to more elaborate designs to really impress your neighbors you can also make soup balls out of them pumpkin soup is delicious and looks really effective presented in hollowed-out pumpkins simply scoop out the flesh making sure that the bowl is sturdy enough to hold the soup you'll find some great these on the internet for creating pumpkin and butternut squash soups finally the pumpkin seeds don't throw away after the carving pumpkin seeds are edible simply scoop them out wash them and dry the seeds sprinkle them with oil salt and pepper and roast them you can use them for a garnish on salads and soups or just eat them as a tasty snack I hope you've enjoyed this video on how to grow pumpkins for Halloween if you have please give this video the thumbs up and don't forget to subscribe to my youtube channel and I'm sure you're going to enjoy this next video on the lifecycle of a pumpkin for kids thanks for watching and bye for now

content: hey everybody today I'm tech with Brett we're gonna show you how to carve a pumpkin don't worry there will be tech involved the first step is you need to find a nice round pumpkin as a flat face also you need to make sure that has a flat bottom so it sits up great and has a stem so that you can easily pull it off so the second step is to go in to Google and search for a pumpkin stencil and you can search for whatever you want and you will most likely find what you're looking for so here this first which is actually what we want and I want this one that just has the outline so I'm not going to waste any ink printing off a picture with all those dark colors so I'm going to open this up and if you hit the settings right here you can go to view original image and then I just want to save that image and now that it is downloaded I'm going to open up a write on my phone and I am going to hit the print samsung print service from my phone depending on what printer you have it may be different and I'm going to choose my HP printer here and I want it full size but we can just go in here and make sure that it is covering up the full page and then I hit print the first step is to remove the top of the pumpkin you can use any knife to cut make sure it's sharp and easy to get into the pumpkin I do prefer the knife that I had as a kid that was in the pumpkin carving kit that we had once you go all the way around if it won't remove try going back around the opposite direction to remove the top then you can cut off the guts of the pumpkin from the top so that you have a nice clean cut there and then the next step is to get a ice-cream scoop or a big spoon and scrape out the insides this will get rid of all the string and pumpkin-seeds easily from the inside of the pumpkin then make sure you have a bowl to place it in so that you don't have a great big mess I usually do this a few times checking to make sure I make it clean and smooth so that there's not any dangling string in the carved pumpkin I ended up having to print out a smaller version of the witch so that it would fit more properly on the pumpkin then I'm going to find the best place to put it and I'm actually just going to pin this right on the outside of the pumpkin I am gonna take a fifth pin and then poke small holes along the outside of my pattern this way it's easy to see once I remove the pattern and I can distinguish what I need to cut out the black pieces are exactly what I want to remove so then I take off the paper and I mark the pattern that I need to follow to cut out this way I don't cut out a piece that is needed to show the shape of my pattern once I go through and mark the outline I then want to make sure that I make a mark with it will show exactly what needs to be cut out and leave blank what needs to stay once I fully trace the pattern then I am ready to begin carving out the pumpkin make sure that when you cut into the pumpkin you cut it straight in and not at an angle this allows the full shape to appear once the pumpkin is illuminated with light when you are carving you want to make sure that you start with the delicate areas first so that the pumpkin is firm and then move to the easier portions near the end once I've completely cut out all objects and I'm going to go through and clean up to make sure that all strings or areas are cut out properly the last part is to put your pumpkin back together place a candle inside and light the candle to enjoy your fine work thank you all for joining me today on tech with Brett if this helped you carve a pumpkin I'd love to hear about your experience in the comments if you want to see more how-to tech videos please click my face in the top right hand corner to subscribe and I hope you all have a safe Halloween

content: we got this pumpkin for a fall decoration but I don't want it to go to waste so I'm gonna cut it open and cook it I'm Jen D from Jenn Dee's general calm and know this is not a pie pumpkin but you can still eat it people use the pie pumpkin so the smaller ones because of having less to deal with and because they are supposed to have a sweeter and more taste but if you're going to put it in bread or soup or cheesecake or pie with a lot of spices and sugar you don't really have to worry about the taste and your pumpkin won't go to waste so I have already washed the pumpkins and gotten all the mud off of it actually my daughter did and I'm going to set it on this side because it's kind of flat and like I wanted to skirt around the middle this way some people cut it this way it doesn't really matter okay keep your hands well back and once the tip is in should be able to just cut around the pumpkin - really going okay okay now the larger pumpkins are going to have more seeds than the smaller ones so if you like roasting pumpkin seeds you might want a bigger one use an ice cream scoop or a regular spoon to scrape all the seeds and pulp out of the center of the pumpkin when you are done scraping it out turn the pumpkin upside down and place it on a baking sheet and put it in the oven at 350 degrees for about 45 minutes if you add some water to your baking tray it will create more steam to help loosen the pumpkin and keep it moist when it is done baking you should be able to easily scoop out the pumpkin with a spoon and then you can mash blend chop strain whatever you want to make the pumpkin as smooth as you want it this is the pumpkin meat that I took out of the baked pumpkin and now I am dividing it into two cups at a time to freeze because that's a good portion for baking pumpkins were originally from Central America but now they are grown all over the world in six of the seven continents they don't grow on Antarctica Mogens are in the squash family so they have lots of good new chance they have vitamin A potassium magnesium calcium and beta-carotene pumpkins have zero cholesterol they are used in a bunch of facial creams and they were once used as a remedy for snake bites nowadays we mostly use them for decorating and baking and that is what I'm going to do with this cup two cups of pumpkin I'm going to make it into pumpkin bread

title: How to Grow a Pumpkin
original_title: How to Cook Pumpkin Seeds
content: ever wonder what to do with those gross stringy seeds that come out of those pumpkins how about cooking them if you'd like to learn how to cook pumpkin seeds it isn't difficult you can roast them toast them in a skillet or even microwave them to make a tasty treat for a Halloween party before you cook pumpkin scenes you may want to first rinse them off and pat dry with a kitchen towel to oven roast the seeds pre-heat your oven to 300 degrees Fahrenheit toss the seeds in a bowl with one to two tablespoons of melted butter or olive oil you can use margarine instead of butter or substitute another type of oil for the olive oil for a lower fat version skip the oil and butter all together and use cooking spray on your baking pan to cook the pumpkin seeds place them in a single layer in an oven safe dish or on a baking sheet sprinkle the pumpkin seeds with salts and bake them for approximately 30 to 40 minutes or until they start to brown be sure to stir the seeds every 10 minutes if you'd like to add other flavors consider adding garlic salt or worse - sure sauce for a sweet and salty flavor you can add sugar cinnamon nutmeg and other spices including cayenne pepper once you've removed the pumpkin seeds from the oven be sure to let them cool before you enjoy them your roasted pumpkin seeds can be stored for about a week sealed in an airtight container for more information on other ways to cook pumpkin seeds visit the link below [Music]

title: How to Grow a Pumpkin
original_title: How to cook a Pumpkin and make Pumpkin Puree
content: [Music] everybody knows what carving a pumpkin is it's the jack-o'-lantern there's just all over the place these days and their thin wall they're about you know this thick in the wall cooking pumpkins or pie pumpkins are at least this thick there are many different varieties there are Cinderella pumpkin the Jarrah Dale pumpkin knucklehead pumpkin which I'll show you it's really pretty kind of cute instead of cutting it up like you would have squash and boiling or steaming it to again additional flavor this is to roast the whole pumpkin so this is what's called a Cinderella pumpkin and the reason it's called Cinderella is because it looks a lot like the carriage that she took the night of her grand ball with the prince just be sure that it's clean by rubbing off the skin of any dirt put it on a baking sheet the most important thing is to be sure to have some ventilation holes so just stick a knife at a few places for steam to escape while the pumpkin is roasting so it doesn't explode and we'll put it in the oven beautiful and just like other carving pumpkin the seeds in the stringy flesh are in the middle I'll get rid of those this Cinderella pumpkin I don't think it's gonna be a carriage tonight now all this wonderful puree can be soup it could be pumpkin butter it could be a filling for pasta oh that's so good doesn't even ND no sugar or even salt that's really actually very good
